facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 356 of 1965 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 27, 1964, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 240 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 356 of 1965. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and decree dated October 27, 1964, of the Madhya Pradesh High Court in Second Appeal No. 240 of 1964.

facts.text: The first respondent Tikam Das let out a house in the city of Jabalpur to the second respondent Surya Kant Naidoo.

anchor.surface_text: The first respondent Tikam Das had let out a house in the city of Jabalpur to the second respondent Surya Kant Naidoo.

facts.text: Sometime in 1961 Tikam Das served a notice on Surya Kant Naidoo terminating the tenancy.

anchor.surface_text: Sometime in 1961 Tikam Das, herein referred to as the landlord, served a numberice on Surya Kant, herein referred to as the tenant, terminating the tenancy

facts.text: Later in the same year 1961 Tikam Das filed a suit in a civil court against Surya Kant Naidoo for ejectment.

anchor.surface_text: and later in the same year filed a suit in a civil companyrt against the latter for ejectment.

facts.text: On June 23, 1962, by consent of parties, a decree for ejectment was passed in favour of the landlord against the tenant.

anchor.surface_text: On June 23, 1962, by companysent of parties, a decree for ejectment was passed in that suit in favour of the landlord against the tenant.

facts.text: The appellants were occupying the premises as sub-tenants under the tenant and had not been made parties to the suit.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants who were occupying the premises as sub-tenants under the tenant had number been made parties to the suit.

facts.text: The Madhya Pradesh Accommodation Control Act, 1961 came into force on December 30, 1961.

anchor.surface_text: of the Madhya Pradesh Accommo- dation Control Act, 1961 which had companye into force on Decem- ber 30, 1961,

facts.text: On June 25 and 26, 1962, the appellants served notices on the landlord under s. 15(2) of the Act claiming sub-letting before the Act with consent of landlord, becoming direct tenants under s. 16(2).

anchor.surface_text: On June 25 and 26, 1962, the appellants served numberices on the landlord under s. 15 2  of the Madhya Pradesh Accommo- dation Control Act, 1961 ... become his direct tenants under s. 16 2  of the Act

facts.text: On June 28, 1962, the appellants filed a suit against both the landlord and the tenant claiming declaration of direct tenancy under the landlord.

anchor.surface_text: and on June 28, 1962, the appellants filed a suit against both the landlord and the tenant in a civil companyrt claiming a declaration that they had in the circumstances become direct tenants

facts.text: On June 30, 1962, the landlord sent a reply to the notices denying that the sub-letting was with his consent or lawful.

anchor.surface_text: On June 30, 1962, the landlord sent a reply to the numberices sent by the appellants in which he denied that the sub-letting by the tenant had been with his companysent or was lawful.

facts.text: The landlord had not put his decree in execution for evicting the appellants.

anchor.surface_text: It does number appear that the landlord had put his decree in execution for evicting the appellants.

facts.text: The High Court held that in view of s. 45(1) of the Act a civil court was not competent to entertain the appellants' suit and dismissed the suit.

anchor.surface_text: One of the points canvassed in the High Court was whether in view of s. 45 1  of the Act a civil companyrt was companypetent to entertain the appellants suit and it held that it was number and in that view of the matter dismissed the suit.

facts.text: There is no dispute that the sub-letting to the appellants was before the Act and they had given the notice under s.15(2).

anchor.surface_text: There is numberdispute that the sub-letting to the appellants was before the Act and they had given the numberice.

facts.text: The landlord contested that the accommodation was not lawfully sub-let.

anchor.surface_text: Where in any case mentioned in sub-section  2 , the landlord companytests that the accommodation was number lawfully sub-let

facts.text: The appellants' suit was filed within the two months period mentioned in s.15(3).

anchor.surface_text: The appellantss suit was filed within the period mentioned in sub-s.  3  of s.

facts.text: The Supreme Court held that the High Court was right that the civil court was incompetent to entertain the suit.

anchor.surface_text: Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a companyrt incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

facts.text: The sub-letting comes within sub-s. 2 of s. 15.

anchor.surface_text: The subletting, therefore, companyes within sub-s.  2  of s. 15.

facts.text: The Rent Controlling Authority has power to decide whether sub-letting was lawful on application within two months.

anchor.surface_text: the Rent Controlling Authority shall decide the dispute. This sub- section empowers a Rent Controlling Authority to decide whether a sub-letting was lawful where the landlord disputes that the subletting was lawful, on an application made to it by either party within the period mentioned.

anchor.surface_text: S. 16.  1  Where, before the companymencement of this Act, the interest of a tenant in respect of any accommodation has been determined without determining the interest of any sub-tenant to whom the accommodation either in whole or in part had been lawfully sub-let, the subtenant shall, with effect from the date of the companymencement of this Act be deemed to have become a tenant holding directly under the landlord on the same terms and companyditions on which the tenant would have held from the landlord, if the tenancy had companytinued.

anchor.surface_text: This sub- section empowers a Rent Controlling Authority to decide whether a sub-letting was lawful where the landlord disputes that the subletting was lawful, on an application made to it by either party within the period mentioned. When the Rent Controlling Authorities have the power to decide the lawfulness of the subletting, a civil companyrt is plainly debarred from deciding that question by s. 45 1 .

arguments.claim: landlord contested that sub-letting was not lawful

holdings.text: The High Court was right in holding that the civil court was incompetent to entertain the appellants' suit under s.45(1) of the Act because the Rent Controlling Authority is empowered to decide the lawfulness of the sub-letting under s.15(3).

anchor.surface_text: This sub- section empowers a Rent Controlling Authority to decide whether a sub-letting was lawful where the landlord disputes that the subletting was lawful, on an application made to it by either party within the period mentioned. When the Rent Controlling Authorities have the power to decide the lawfulness of the subletting, a civil court is plainly debarred from deciding that question by s. 45 1 . In the present case the landlord did contest that the sub-letting was not lawful. The appellants' suit was filed within the period mentioned in sub-s.  3  of s. So the Rent Controlling Authorities had the power to decide the question on which the appellants suit depended. It follows that the suit related to a matter which the Rent Controlling Authorities had power to decide and no civil court was, therefore, competent to entertain it. Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a court incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Suit seeks declaration of direct tenancy under s.16(2) which depends on lawfulness of pre-Act sub-letting; s.15(3) empowers RCA to decide such disputes if notice under s.15(2) given and application within 2 months; landlord contested; suit filed timely; thus s.45(1) bars civil court.

holdings.text: The sub-letting falls within s.15(2) as it occurred before the Act and notice was given.

anchor.surface_text: There is no dispute that the sub-letting to the appellants was before the Act and they had given the notice. The subletting, therefore, comes within sub-s. 2 of s. 15.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Undisputed facts: sub-letting pre-Act; appellants served notice under s.15(2).

holdings.text: s.15(3) applies even where landlord obtained decree for eviction against tenant before the suit.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. There is nothing in sub-s. 3 of s. 15 to indicate that it does not apply to a case where a landlord has obtained such a decree. If in spite of the decree the appellants had a right under the Act to a direct tenancy under the landlord, they had a right to move the Rent Controlling Authority within the period mentioned not expired for a decision of the question that the sub-letting to them was lawful.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No textual indication in s.15(3) excluding cases with prior eviction decree; sub-tenants retain right to approach RCA timely for declaration of lawful sub-letting.

holdings.text: Landlord's failure to apply under s.15(3) does not deem sub-letting lawful or confer jurisdiction on civil court.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the sub-section lend no support to this contention. The appellants can claim the direct tenancy only when they establish that the sub-letting to them was lawful. As they claim that right, they must establish it and they do not do so by the failure of the landlord to move for a decision that the sub-letting was not lawful. This contention of the appellants seems to us to be untenable.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sub-tenants bear burden to prove lawfulness; landlord's non-application does not prove lawfulness or remove RCA's exclusive jurisdiction while time limit subsists.

holdings.text: s.45(2) does not permit civil court jurisdiction as the suit does not raise a question of pre-existing title to accommodation but an Act-created right to direct tenancy.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory definition of 'accommodation'; 'title' interpreted as pre-Act interests, not statutory rights like s.16(2) direct tenancy; consistent with Act's scheme assigning such disputes to RCA.

Harmonious construction interpretation consistent with the Act's scheme supports the holding that s.45(2) excludes civil court jurisdiction by distinguishing Act-created rights from pre-existing title questions.

DOCTRINE_HARMONIOUS_CONSTRUCTION provides interpretation consistent with Act's scheme for assigning disputes to Rent Controlling Authority, directly addressing the issue of whether the suit raises a question of title under s.45(2) to determine jurisdiction.
Section 15(2) supports holding empowering Rent Controlling Authority over pre-Act sub-letting disputes.

anchor.surface_text: This sub- section empowers a Rent Controlling Authority to decide whether a sub-letting was lawful where the landlord disputes that the subletting was lawful, on an application made to it by either party within the period mentioned. When the Rent Controlling Authorities have the power to decide the lawfulness of the subletting, a civil court is plainly debarred from deciding that question by s. 45 1 . In the present case the landlord did contest that the sub-letting was not lawful. The appellants' suit was filed within the period mentioned in sub-s.  3  of s. So the Rent Controlling Authorities had the power to decide the question on which the appellants suit depended. It follows that the suit related to a matter which the Rent Controlling Authorities had power to decide and no civil court was, therefore, competent to entertain it. Hence we think that the High Court was right in deciding that the suit had been filed in a court incompetent to entertain it, and in dismissing it.

edges.explanation: h1's affirmation of s.45(1) bar because RCA empowered addresses i6's question on post-limitation civil jurisdiction

anchor.surface_text: We are unable to accept this contention. There is nothing in sub-s. 3 of s. 15 to indicate that it does not apply to a case where a landlord has obtained such a decree. If in spite of the decree the appellants had a right under the Act to a direct tenancy under the landlord, they had a right to move the Rent Controlling Authority within the period mentioned not expired for a decision of the question that the sub-letting to them was lawful.
For these reasons, in our view, numbercivil companyrt had jurisdiction to try the appellants suit and it was rightly dismissed as having been filed in an incompetent tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: The words of the sub-section lend no support to this contention. The appellants can claim the direct tenancy only when they establish that the sub-letting to them was lawful. As they claim that right, they must establish it and they do not do so by the failure of the landlord to move for a decision that the sub-letting was not lawful. This contention of the appellants seems to us to be untenable.
For these reasons, in our view, numbercivil companyrt had jurisdiction to try the appellants suit and it was rightly dismissed as having been filed in an incompetent tribunal.
